description.content: In this lesson we will practise expressing simple feelings about objects with adjectives. Two forms of adjective use will be practiced. First we will learn a form called suki1, where the adjective is located at the end of the sentence and describes feelings about one noun. We will also consider a related form called suki2 where the adjective refers to an activity described by a simple sentence. To show how adjectives can modify verbs as adverbs, we'll look at sentences expressing changes in the size or number of objects. Finally, we will also learn the past form for each kind of adjective introduced in this lesson.

u.b: Grammar Point 1: Expressing feelings about objects and activities

grammar_points.p: The "na" adjective 好き is used to express one's positive feelings about an object or activity. It is equivalent to the expressions "to enjoy" or "to like" in English. In this lesson, the suki1 form is just the standard form for "na" adjectives that you practised in the previous lesson.

tr.td: 私はオレンジジュースが好きです - "I like orange juice."
私はコーラが好きではありません - "I don't like cola."

grammar_points.p: The example sentences above express feelings about a noun, so the adjective modifies the noun in question. A similar pattern that we call the suki2 form can be used for expressing feelings about an activity, but in this case the adjective modifies a simple sentence consisting of a verb followed by the marker の instead of a noun. The only difference between this form and the suki1 form is the phrase modified by the adjective, so the forms of the adjective itself are exactly the same.

tr.td: 私はコーヒーを飲むのが好きです - "I like drinking coffee."
私は勉強するのが好きではありません - "I don't like studying."

u.b: Grammar Point 2: Using adjectives as adverbs to express changes in size or number

grammar_points.p: The examples below show an expression used to indicate that the size or quantity of an object (described by an adjective) has changed. This expression consists of an "i" adjective describing size or quantity followed by the verb なる ("to become"). To create the negative form of this pattern, we simply use the negative past form of the verb.

tr.td: 魚は大きくなりました - "The fish became bigger."
リンゴは多くなりました - "The apples became numerous." (The number of apples increased.)
魚は大きくなりませんでした - "The fish didn't become bigger."
リンゴは多くなりませんでした - "The apples didn't become more numerous." (The number of apples didn't increase.)

grammar_points.p: This pattern is actually an example of an adjective being used as an adverb to modify a verb. When an adjective is used in this way, the final "i" sound changes to "ku" and the verb that is modified directly follows the adjective. We will only consider the following adjectives in this lesson, but in general any "i" adjective can be used.
